acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours LC50=7microg/L(Copper Sulfate Anhydride Equivalent: 17microg/L) of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (EHC200, 1998).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 300mg/kg (EHC 200 (1998)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible based on expert judgment in the absence of existing classification (though some toxicity data are available).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in ATSDR (2004) and EHC 200 (1998).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing oxygen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of malformation and adverse effects on postnatal development of pups, described in ATSDR (2004), EHC 200 (1998) and CERI Hazard Data 2001-59 (2002) (though no data are available regarding parental animals).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: The decomposition temperature is >560degC (Merck (13th, 2001)), whereas the kick-off temperature is considered to exceed 75degC.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description of the human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2001-59 (2002)): "The substance induces strong irritation of the eye," "produces conjunctivitis, edema in the eyelid, and corneal ulcer and opacities on contact with the eye." The substance is classified into Category 1 since corneal ulceration, which involves tissue damage, is considered to have irreversible effects.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) 2001: "Severely irritates the eye and skin; inhalation of aerosols causes respiratory irritation; oral ingestion results in corrosion." The substance is thus considered to be corrosive to the skin.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on two epidemiological case reports that suggest skin sensitizing potential in humans (EHC 200 (1998)). Also due to the fact that the substance is classified into "Group 2" (as copper or its compounds) by the Japan Society for Occupational Health, and a "Skin Sensitizing Substance" (as copper) by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy (2004).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "hemolytic anemia was noted," "pathological alterations include pulmonary inflammation, formation of granulomas, fibrohyaline nodules, desquamation of macrophages, and progression of diffuse fibrosis" (ATSDR (2004)), "repeated or prolonged exposure to aerosols may result in lung damage" (ICSC (J) (2001)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (blood system, liver, nervous system, kidney),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (blood system, liver, nervous system, kidney)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "Death occurred due to methemoglobinemia; copper sulfate causes liver damage, inducing centrolobular necrosis and cholestasis in severe cases; glomerular congestion, desquamation of renal tubular cells, hemoglobin cast were reported on the deceased subjects," "nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal pain, diarrhea, hypotension, hematemesis or discharge of blood from the anus, jaundice, delirium, coma, intravascular hemolysis, oliguresis and anuria were observed" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-59 (2002)), "severely irritates the eye and skin; inhalation of aerosols produces respiratory irritation" (ICSC (J) (2001)).
